DRUMS BEAT LOUDER FOR A BLOOMBERG RUN  |  Michael R. Bloomberg has been fielding calls from his Wall Street friends in recent months, all asking why he doesn’t run for president,
Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

William A. Ackman, who has supported Democratic candidates in the past, buttonholed him at a dinner party and urged him to run. Mr. Ackman later publicly declared, “I would do everything in my power to get this guy elected.”

Even so, Mr. Bloomberg has maintained to most of his friends that it’s “not going to happen.”

The interest in a possible presidential run has increased as anxiety has mounted that Hillary Rodham Clinton has been forced to move too far left on business and tax issues. Republican business voters are also concerned that Jeb Bush has been drowned out by the attention heaped on Donald Trump. 

Business executives also contend that none of the candidates can match Mr. Bloomberg’s experience of building his own business empire and running New York City.

Of course, these sentiments may not resonate outside New York and Wall Street’s interest in Mr. Bloomberg could become a liability. But Mr. Trump’s position at the top of polls has overturned the conventional wisdom that a billionaire is unelectable. 

Mr. Bloomberg, however, does not want to run unless he can win. According to friends, he has said he cannot run as a Republican because of his views on gun control and global warming. He also doesn’t believe he can run as a Democrat because of his connections to Wall Street, his wealth and his “stop and frisk” policies as mayor. So he would have to run as an independent. 

He could easily get on the ballot in all 50 states, and polling conducted privately years ago suggested he might be able to win a plurality of the popular vote. But if he did not receive the majority of the votes in the  Electoral College, he would be at the mercy of the House to vote on the presidency. And that is where he thinks he is likely to lose because lawmakers would vote along party lines. 

Nonetheless, the door isn’t completely shut. Mr. Bloomberg has told friends that if in March, the deadline for when an independent candidate would need to declare a run, the leading candidates were in his view problematic, he would reconsider. But only if he could win.




MISTRIAL IS DECLARED IN DEWEY & LEBOEUF CASE  |  The monthslong case against three former executives of Dewey & LeBoeuf resulted in a mistrial as the jury deadlocked on dozens of charges after 21 days of deliberations, 

Matthew Goldstein reports in DealBook.

The mixed conclusion leaves the defendants, Steven H. Davis, Stephen DiCarmine and Joel Sanders, in limbo. They could still be tried again on the deadlocked charges.

It also deals a blow to  Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, just after legal defeats in two other prominent white-collar cases. 

Mr. Vance’s office issued a statement that said the hung jury may “necessitate a retrial pending a thorough review of the case.” The statement noted that prosecutors believed the defendants had broken the law.

The jury of 12 had acquitted the defendants on dozens of charges already, but they told the trial judge that they remained “hopelessly deadlocked” on the remaining 93 charges, which included the most serious offenses, like grand larceny and scheme to defraud. Several jurors interviewed afterward said the jury had been divided and some were confused by the more than 151 charges.

The defendants were accused of plotting to manipulate financial records in an effort to defraud bank lenders and insurance companies during the financial crisis. Dewey’s bankruptcy in 2012 was one of the biggest collapses of a law firm in the nation’s history. 

The length of the deliberations and the decision that it was a mistrial will raise questions about whether the case was too complex. 

One juror, Skylar Schur, a high school teacher, said that some jurors were “looking for a smoking gun” to convict the defendants, even though the prosecutors had cautioned against looking at evidence that way. 

She also said that there were heated arguments between jurors early on in the deliberations and the jury had requested a set of markers to prepare a timeline of events.

SALE OF STUYVESANT TOWN IS EXPECTED TO PRESERVE MIDDLE-CLASS HOUSING  |  Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village, the largest apartment complex in Manhattan, is expected to be sold for more than $5.3 billion, according to officials involved in the negotiations, 

Charles V. Bagli reports in The New York Times. The agreement will preserve nearly half of the 11,232-unit complex for middle-class families.

The sale, to the Blackstone Group, includes an agreement that a block of 5,000 apartments will remain affordable for families of teachers, construction workers, firefighters and others who have traditionally lived there. The rest of the complex is leased at market rents, which make it prohibitively expensive for many. 

In return for maintaining the affordable block, the city agreed to waive $77 million in mortgage recording taxes and to provide Blackstone with a $144 million low-interest loan through the Housing Development Corporation. Blackstone also agreed not to pursue a condominium conversion or to build towers on the property.

The terms of the deal allow Blackstone to phase in market-rate rents over five years for an additional 1,200 apartments when certain tax benefits wear off in 2020.

It is a victory for Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has made affordable housing a priority of his administration and for tenant activists and elected officials who feared that Stuyvesant Town’s 65-year history as a middle-class bastion was ending. 

The 110 redbrick buildings that make up the complex have been the focus of a roiling debate over house prices, which are increasingly putting ownership out of the reach of middle-income New Yorkers, as well as the poor. 

The last time the complex sold, the $5.4 billion deal set off an outcry over affordable housing as the buyers sought to replace longtime, rent-regulated residents with higher-paying tenants. The debt-laden owners ultimately lost the complex to their lender when they ran out of money. 

In light of that debacle in 2006, the de Blasio administration, Senator Chuck Schumer, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and other elected officials were determined to prevent another speculative buyer from buying Stuyvesant Town and turning it into a luxury complex.

According to people involved in the negotiations, Blackstone was the only company willing to work with the city and the tenants, immediately offering to preserve a large block for middle-income tenants.
